tit.e: Shinsen (Food and Alcohol Offering to the Gods)
Shinsen (Food and Alcohol Offering to the Gods)
Shinsen (Food and Alcohol Offering to the gods)

sen.j: 神饌（しんせん）とは、日本の神社や神棚に供える供物の事である。
sen.e: Shinsen is an offering to shrines and household Shinto altar in Japan.
Shinsen is an offering to shrines and household Shinto altars in Japan.
Shinsen is an offering to shrines and household Shinto altars in Japan.

sen.j: 御饌（みけ）あるいは御贄（みにえ）とも言う。
sen.e: It is also called Mike or Minie.
It is also called Mike or Minie.
It is also called Mike or Minie.

sen.j: 神饌には、調理して供える熟饌（じゅくせん）と、生のまま供える生饌（せいせん）とがある。
sen.e: The Mike includes the cooked type called Jukusen and the raw type called Seisen.
Mike includes the cooked type called Jukusen and the raw type called Seisen.
Shinsen includes the cooked type called Jukusen and the raw type called Seisen.

sen.j: 熟饌の調理には、本来は燧石、舞錐式などで起こした神聖な炎（忌火・いみび）のみを使う。
sen.e: To cook the Jukusen, in principle, only flames (secret fire (imibi)) produced by firestones or maigirishiki is used.
To cook the Jukusen, in principle, only flames (secret fire or imibi) produced by firestones or maigirishiki is used.
To cook the Jukusen, in principle, only flames (secret fire (imibi)) produced by firestones or maigiri-shiki (style using gimlets (maigiri), ancient tools for making fire) is used.
sen.cmt: 舞錐式の表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 神社などでは、米、塩、水、野菜、鯛、鰹節（干鰹）、海藻、果物、清酒などを供える。
sen.e: In shrines, offerings include rice, salt, water, vegetables, bonitos, dried bonito, see feed, fruits, and seishu or refined sake.
In shrines, offerings include rice, salt, water, vegetables, bonitos, dried bonito, see feed, fruits, and seishu or refined sake.
In shrines, offerings include rice, salt, water, vegetables, bonitos, dried bonito, seaweed, fruits, and seishu or refined sake.

sen.j: 基本的には、かわらけと呼ばれる素焼きの焼き物を器にするが、地域によってはアワビの貝殻を代用する場合もある。
sen.e: Although Shinsen is usually offered in a unglazed vessel called Kawarake (earthen cup), an abalone shell may be used in some regions.
Although Shinsen is usually offered in a unglazed vessel called Kawarake (earthenware cup), an abalone shell may be used in some regions.
Although Shinsen is usually offered in a unglazed vessel called Kawarake (earthenware cup), an abalone shell may be used in some regions.

sen.j: 本来、朝夕の2回供えるが、地域によって異なっている。
sen.e: It is, in principle, served twice a day--morning and evening--but how often it is served a day may vary from region to region.
It is, in principle, served twice a day--morning and evening--but how often it is served a day may vary from region to region.
It is, in principle, served twice a day--morning and evening--but how often it is served a day may vary from region to region.

sen.j: 祭儀の後に供えた神饌を食べる宴のことを直会（なおらい）という。
sen.e: Nnaorai refers to the Shinsen eaten in a feast after a ceremony.
Nnaorai refers to Shinsen eaten in a feast after a ceremony.
Naorai refers to Shinsen eaten in a feast after a ceremony.

sen.j: 直会には、神の供物を食べることで神に近づくという意味もあるが、人が食べることのできないものは供えてはいなかったという証明でもある。
sen.e: Eating the Nnaorai not only means getting closer to a god by eating what has been offered but also proves that things unfit to eat have not offered.
Eating the Nnaorai not only means getting closer to a god by eating what has been offered, but also proves that things unfit to eat have not been offered.
Eating the Naorai not only means getting closer to a god by eating what has been offered, but also proves that things unfit to eat have not been offered.

sen.j: ただ、厳密に言うならば、献饌された神饌が必ず直会にあがるという訳ではない。
sen.e: Strictly speaking, however, the Shinsen offered on the altars is not necessarily served as a Naorai.
Strictly speaking, however, the Shinsen offered on the altars is not necessarily served as a Naorai.
Strictly speaking, however, the Shinsen offered on the altars is not necessarily served as a Naorai.

sen.j: 献饌し終わった神饌を神体山へ投げる、土中に埋めるなどの行為が今現在でも一部見られる。
sen.e: In some regions, the Shinsen offered on the altars are thrown in Shintaizan (a mountain where the spirit of deity is traditionally believed to dwell) or buried underground even today.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In some regions, the Shinsen offered on the altars are thrown in Shintaizan (a mountain where the spirit of deity is traditionally believed to dwell) or buried underground even today.
In some regions, the Shinsen offered on the altars is thrown in Shintaizan (a mountain where the spirit of deity is traditionally believed to dwell) or buried underground even today.
sen.cmt: 前出の表記に合わせShinsenに続く動詞を"are"→"is"に修正しました。

sen.j: 各々神饌に対しての礼儀作法、考え方が異なっていたこと、それらが今でも継承されてきたことが伺える。
sen.e: This indicates that there were different courtesies or stances toward Shinsen, which have been passed down to the present day.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: This indicates that there were different courtesies or stances toward Shinsen, which have been passed down to the present day.
This indicates that there were different courtesies or stances toward Shinsen, which have been passed down to the present day.

sen.j: 現在、多くの神社における神饌は生饌が多く扱われているが、有名古社や古い神事を継承し続けている神社においてはきわめて珍しい形式の神饌を献饌していることがある。
sen.e: The Shisen offered in many shrines is Seisen today but quite a rare style of Seisen has been offered in some well known and old shrines or other shrines that have carried on traditional Shinto rituals.

The Shisen offered in many shrines is Seisen today but quite a rare style of Seisen has been offered in some well known and old shrines or other shrines that have carried on traditional Shinto rituals.

The Shinsen offered in many shrines is Seisen (raw type) today but quite a rare style of Shinsen has been offered in some well known and old shrines or other shrines that have carried on traditional Shinto rituals.
sen.cmt: Shinsen, Seisenの誤表記を訂正し、生饌の意味を明確にするため補足を入れました。

sen.j: 便宜上、それらは特殊神饌と呼ばれ、熟饌を中心とした、調理されたものが献饌されている。
sen.e: Such a rare Seisen is called Special Seisen, for convenience, and Seisen, a cooked type, is mainly offered..
Such a rare Seisen is called Special Seisen, for convenience, and Seisen, a cooked type, is mainly offered..
Such a rare Shinsen is called Special Shinsen, for convenience, and Jukusen, a cooked type, is mainly offered..
sen.cmt: 神饌の表記をSeisen→Shinsenに訂正、および熟饌の表記をSeisen→Jukusenに訂正しました。

sen.j: （神社祭式に規定されたものを基準として考えているので、それまで存在していた古式の神饌は「特殊」という括りで称されるようになった。
sen.e: (Because the standard Seisen is considered as what is defined in the Rules for Ritual Procedure at Shrines, the traditional Seisen has been seen as "Special," and called so.
(Because standard Seisen is considered to be what is defined in the Rules for Ritual Procedures at Shrines, the traditional Seisen has been seen as "Special," and called so.
(Because standard Shinsen is considered to be what is defined in the Rules for Ritual Procedures at Shrines, the traditional Shinsen has been seen as "Special," and called so.
sen.cmt: 神饌の表記をSeisen→Shinsenに訂正しました。

sen.j: 明治維新を境にした神社祭式の刷新と神社の在り方・神道のあり方が大きく影響を及ぼしている）
sen.e: This is greatly influenced by a reform of the Rules for Ritual Procedure at Shrines as well as a changed meaning of shrines and Shinto after Maiji Restoration.
This is greatly influenced by the reform of the Rules for Ritual Procedures at Shrines as well as the change in meaning of shrines and Shinto after Meiji Restoration.
This is greatly influenced by the reform of the Rules for Ritual Procedures at Shrines as well as the change in meaning of shrines and Shinto after Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 一例を挙げるならば、以下のようなものがある。
sen.e: Examples of Special Shinsen are:
Examples of Special Shinsen are:
Examples of Special Shinsen are:

sen.j: 奈良県奈良市 春日大社 春日若宮おん祭り 『御染御供』
sen.e: "Osome goku" in Kasuga Wakamiya Onmatsuri Festival of Kasuga Taisha Shrine, Nara City, Nara Prefecture
"Osome goku" in the Kasuga Wakamiya Onmatsuri Festival of Kasuga Taisha Shrine, Nara City, Nara Prefecture
"Osome Goku" in the Kasuga Wakamiya Onmatsuri Festival of Kasuga-taisha Shrine, Nara City, Nara Prefecture
sen.cmt: クォーテーション内の頭文字を大文字に、およびKasuga-taisha Shrineとしました。

sen.j: 奈良県奈良市 春日大社 春日祭 『御戸開八種神饌』『御棚神饌』
sen.e: "Mitobiraki yakusano shinsen" and "Mitana shinsen" in Kasuga Wakamiya Onmatsuri Festival of Kasuga Taisha Shrine, Nara City, Nara Prefecture
"Mitobiraki yakusano shinsen" and "Mitana shinsen" in Kasuga Wakamiya Onmatsuri Festival of Kasuga Taisha Shrine, Nara City, Nara Prefecture
"Mitobiraki Yakusa no Shinsen" and "Mitana Shinsen" in Kasuga Matsuri Festival of Kasuga-taisha Shrine, Nara City, Nara Prefecture
sen.cmt: クォーテーション内の頭文字を大文字に、および"Yakusa no"としました。"Kasuga Wakamiya Onmatsuri Festival"→"Kasuga Matsuri Festival"に訂正しました。"Kasuga-taisha Shrine"としました。

sen.j: 奈良県奈良市 率川神社 率川祭 『率川祭神饌』
sen.e: "Isagawa matsuri shinsen" in Isagawa Matsuri Festival of Isagawa Shrine, Nara City, Nara Prefecture
"Isagawa matsuri shinsen" in Isagawa Matsuri Festival of Isagawa Shrine, Nara City, Nara Prefecture
"Isagawa Matsuri Shinsen" in Isagawa Matsuri Festival of Isagawa-jinja Shrine, Nara City, Nara Prefecture

sen.j: 奈良県桜井市 多武峰 談山神社 嘉吉祭 『百味御食』
sen.e: "Hyakumi onjiki" in Kakissai Festival of Tanzan Shrine, Tonomine, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture
"Hyakumi onjiki" in Kakissai Festival of Tanzan Shrine, Tonomine, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture
"Hyakumi Onjiki" in Kakissai Festival of Tanzan-jinja Shrine, Tonomine, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture

sen.j: 京都府京都市 賀茂御祖神社・賀茂別雷神社 葵祭 『内陣神饌』『外陣神饌』『庭積神饌』
sen.e: "Naijin shinsen," "gaijin shinsen," and "niwazumi shinsen" in Aoi-Matsuri Festival of Kamomioya-jinja Shrine/Kamowake-Ikazuchi-jinja Shrine, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture

sen.e: "Yuki omike" of Ise Jingu shrine, Ise City, Mie Prefecture

sen.j: 滋賀県大津市 日吉大社 山王祭 『粟津御供』
sen.e: "Awazu no goku" in Sanno Matsuri Festival of Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture
"Awazu no goku" in Sanno Matsuri Festival of Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture

sen.e: "Aofushigaki shinji shinsen" in Aofushigaki shinji of Miho-jinja Shrine, Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture

sen.j: 新潟県弥彦村 彌彦神社 灯篭神事 『大御膳』
sen.e: "Ogozen" in Toro shinji of Iyahiko-jinja Shrine, Yahiko Mura, Nigata Prefecture
"Ogozen" in Toro shinji of Iyahiko-jinja Shrine, Yahiko Mura, Nigata Prefecture
"Ogozen" in Toro shinji of Iyahiko-jinja Shrine, Yahiko-mura, Nigata Prefecture

sen.e: "Ontosai shinsen" in Ontosai Festival of Suwa Taisha shrine, Suwa City, Nagano Prefecture
"Ontosai shinsen" in Ontosai Festival of Suwa Taisha shrine, Suwa City, Nagano Prefecture
"Ontosai Shinsen" in Ontosai Festival of Suwa-taisha Shrine, Suwa City, Nagano Prefecture

sen.e: "Daikyosai shinsen" in Daikyosai of Katori-jingu Shrine, Katori city, Chiba Prefecture
"Daikyosai shinsen" in Daikyosai of Katori-jingu Shrine, Katori city, Chiba Prefecture
"Daikyosai Shinsen" in Daikyosai Festival of Katori-jingu Shrine, Katori city, Chiba Prefecture

sen.j: 近畿地方などでは小さな社でも特殊神饌を献饌する神事・祭祀儀礼を伝承・継続しているところがある。
sen.e: Some small shrines in Kinki region have handed down and carried on traditional Shinto rituals and services in which Special Shinsen is offered on the altar.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Some small shrines in the Kinki region have been handed down and carried on traditional Shinto rituals and services in which Special Shinsen is offered on the altar.
Some small shrines in the Kinki region have been handed down and carried on traditional Shinto rituals and services in which Special Shinsen is offered on the altar.

sen.j: 神道学・民俗学・食文化研究などの研究対象になることも多い。
sen.e: The Special Shinsen in those shrines are often the subject of researches in the studies of Shinto, folklore, and food culture.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Special Shinsen in those shrines are often the subject of research into the studies of Shinto, folklore, and food culture.
The Special Shinsen in those shrines are often the subject of research into the studies of Shinto, folklore, and food culture.

sen.j: 各々の特殊神饌は、各社の地域産業や神社経済、信仰の在り様、祭祀儀礼の意義など複雑な要素が見え隠れしている。
sen.e: Various factors such as the regional industry, finance of shrines, the way of practicing a faith, and purposes of Shinto services and rituals can be glimpsed in each Special Shinsen.
Various factors such as the regional industry, financing of shrines, the way of practicing faith, and purposes of Shinto services and rituals can be glimpsed at in each Special Shinsen.
Various factors such as the regional industry, financing of shrines, the way of practicing faith, and purposes of Shinto services and rituals can be glimpsed at in each Special Shinsen.

sen.j: 日本人が生み出した食文化の一つとして着目すべき宗教現象だと言えると思われる。
sen.e: The Special Shinsen can be regarded as a remarkable religious phenomenon as a food culture developed by the Japanese.
Special Shinsen can be regarded as a remarkable religious phenomenon as a food culture developed by the Japanese.
Special Shinsen can be regarded as a remarkable religious phenomenon as a food culture developed by the Japanese.
